metadata.title: New Insight in Fabrication of a Sensitive Nano-Magnetite/Glutamine/Carbon Based Electrochemical Sensor for Determination of Aspirin and Omeprazole

sections.text:
Journal of The Electrochemical Society, 166 (2) B161-B172 (2019) B161 0013-4651/2019/166(2)/B161/12/$38.00 © The Electrochemical Society
New Insight in Fabrication of a Sensitive Nano-Magnetite/Glutamine/Carbon Based Electrochemical Sensor for Determination of Aspirin and Omeprazole Nada F. Atta, z Ahmed Galal, Ekram H. El-Ads, and Aya E. Galal
Chemistry Department, Faculty of Science, Cairo University, 12613 Giza, Egypt
In the present study, we introduce a direct and sensitive voltammetry approach for the simultaneous determination of aspirin (ASA) and omeprazole (OMZ) for patients suffering from cardiovascular diseases and gastrointestinal disorders. Low dose of ASA can be used for the prevention of cardiovascular diseases which is considered the most severe cause of mortality worldwide. On the other hand, OMZ can reduce the risk of gastric ulcers and gastrointestinal damage associated with ASA. The used electrode was constructed by in situ-modification with multi-walled carbon nanotubes, glutamine, and nano-magnetite in presence of sodium dodecyl sulfate (FeGluCNTCP-SDS). Using this sensor, the limits of detection were 11.9 nmol·L−1 and 3.3 nmol·L−1 for ASA and OMZ, respectively. The proposed sensor was used for the determination of OMZ in presence of dopamine, paracetamol, ascorbic acid, and uric acid without noticeable interference in their binary or ternary mixtures. The proposed surface showed good analytical performance toward OMZ determination and has a promising application for the electrochemical sensing of other drugs of pharmaceutical importance. © 2019 The Electrochemical Society. [DOI: 10.1149/2.1241902jes]
Manuscript submitted November 12, 2018; revised manuscript received January 2, 2019. Published February 5, 2019.
Omeprazole (OMZ) is considered as a substituted benzimidazole drug consumed worldwide and acted as gastric acid pump inhibitor (Scheme 1A).1,2 OMZ, an antiulcer drug, is widely used to cure the gastric, Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, and duodenal ulcers, and various gastrointestinal disorders such as gastroesophageal reflux disease, erosive esophagitis, pathologic hypersecretory conditions, etc. It can efficiently control and inhibit the production, and secretion of gastric acid by its covalent binding to the proton pump (H+/K+ ATPase) on the gastric parietal cells surfaces and thus preventing the last step in the hydrogen ions secretion into the gastric lumen.1–8,11 OMZ is very beneficial for patients suffering from Zollinger-Ellison syndrome and are not responding to histamine H2receptor antagonist by controlling the gastric acidity.4,7 Besides, it can be used for killing Helicobacter pylori by its combined action with antibiotics.2,8,10 The quality control assessment of this drug in pharmaceutical formulations and biological samples is required due to its widespread and worldwide commercialization. Different analytical methods have been used such as HPLC with coulometric detection,13 liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry,14 thin layer chromatography, capillary electrophoresis,15 UV-spectrophotometry,16 etc. These methods show some drawbacks like high cost, complicated and timeconsuming process, contamination, and high detection limits.9,11,12 Electrochemical methods have been applied as substituent for the as-mentioned methods curing their defects and drawbacks. The electrochemical behavior of OMZ have been reported at different modified surfaces based on carbon paste electrode (CP),3,7 edge plane pyrolytic graphite,12 glassy carbon electrode,6,8 boron-doped diamond electrode,9 poly(alizarin),10 nickel oxide nanoparticles,11 graphene,4 and carbon nanotubes (CNTs).1,2,5
On the other hand, aspirin or acetyl salicylic acid (ASA) is considered one of the most significant worldwide antipyretic, analgesic, antithrombotic, anti-clotting, and non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (Scheme 1B). It is prescribed for the relief of pains, fever reduction, treatement of heart attack, cardiovascular and coronary heart diseases; acts as stroke antithrombotic, and for the inhibition of colon cancer and curing Alzheimer’s. However, the over- and long-term dosage level of ASA is critical owing to its severe side effects like nausea, stomach pain, vomiting, hearing loss, heartbreak, and gastrointestinal damage problems.17–19
Therefore, ASA; an antiplatelet agent, and OMZ; a proton pump inhibitor, can be used together as a binary therapy for the prevention of cardiovascular diseases and heart problems (stroke or heart attack), besides reducing the risk of developing gastric ulcers and gastrointestinal damage associated with ASA. Cardiovascular diseases
zE-mail: anada@sci.cu.edu.eg
are considered the most severe cause of mortality all over the world and it can be prevented by the aid of low dose of ASA which may be unfortunately associated with severe effects in the gastrointestinal tract. Therefore, binary therapy of ASA and OMZ has been proved to be the most operative and influential medication for patients under cardiovascular diseases (heart problems) and in patients at risk for aspirin-associated gastric ulcers.20
CNTs, allotrope of carbon with a cylindrical tube nanostructure discovered by Iijima in 1991, have great applications in energy conversion, lithium battery, supercapacitors, sensors, biosensors, composite materials (coatings or fillers), nanoelectronics, disease biomarkers, etc. The breakthrough in CNTs applications compared to other nanomaterials is attributed to their exceptional electronic, chemical, physical, magnetic, and mechanical characteristics. CNTs, with nanoscale needle shape and well-ordered arrangement via sp2 bonds, showed good biocompatibility, ability of immobilization of different molecules at their surfaces, high surface to volume ratio, enhanced stability, and sensitivity, large surface area for analytes adsorption, and unique strength, rigidity, and conductivity.21–25 CNTs/magnetic iron oxide (Fe3O4) nanocomposites have been reported as active and durable electro-catalyst for sensor and biosensor applications combining the characteristics of both CNTs, and Fe3O4.25–31 Fe3O4 magnetic nanoparticles displayed fascinating features of low toxicity, facile preparation, good biocompatibility, large surface area/volume ratio, and superparamagnetic properties.27,29 CNTs/Fe3O4 nanocomposite was expected to show high sensitivity, good stability, biocompatibility, mediated charge transfer kinetics/fast mass transfer, and enhanced surface area compared to that of CNTs, or Fe3O4 individually.25–31
Modification of CNTs with amino acids like glycine has recently developed for sensing and bio sensing applications. Atta et al. has used CNTs modified with simple amino acid, for the enhancement of the electrochemical response toward DOPAC electro-oxidation compared to CNTs alone.24 Besides, the electroanalytical performance of CNTs can be promoted by polymerization of amino acid over CNTs paste electrode,32–34 or immobilization of CNTs over poly(amino acid) modified surface.35 Glutamine (Glu) is non-essential amino acid with a chain containing one carboxyl group, one amino group, and one amide group. Nor Azah Yusof et al. modified a Pt electrode with a physical mixture of CNTs, Glu and Nafion and proved the electrocatalytic activity of this nanocomposite toward the determination of As (III). They proved the role of Glu in enhancing the electro-catalytic activity of the modified electrode compared to unmodified one.36
The present work depicted an electrochemical approach, which was not described elsewhere, for the sensitive determination of ASA and OMZ in their binary mixture for patients under cardiovascular diseases and gastrointestinal disorders. Also, it depicted the determi-
) unless CC License in place (see abstract). ecsdl.org/site/terms_use address. Redistribution subject to ECS terms of use (see 161.116.100.31Downloaded on 2019-02-06 to IP
Scheme 1. Chemical structures of (A) OMZ, and (B) ASA.
nation of OMZ in presence of other interfering compounds such as paracetamol, dopamine, ascorbic acid, and uric acid. This study was based on the modification of CP with CNTs, Glu, and Fe3O4 in the presence of sodium dodecyl sulfate; FeGluCNTCP-SDS. Also, lower detection limit of OMZ, and good sensitivity have been achieved compared to other electrochemical, and analytical methods. The validity of the applied method for the real analysis of ASA, and OMZ in their pharmaceutical formulations has been described.

sections.heading: Experimental
sections.text:
Reagents and solutions.—Graphite powder (<20 μm, synthetic), paraffin oil, glutamine, iron (III) oxide nano-magnetite (Fe3O4, diameter < 50 nm), multi-walled carbon nanotubes (CNTs, length = 0.1–10 μm, > 90%), dopamine (DA), epinephrine (EP), uric acid (UA), ascorbic acid (AA), paracetamol (APAP), and sodium dodecyl sulfate (SDS) were purchased from Aldrich Chem. Co. (Milwaukee, WI. USA). Omeprazole (OMZ) and aspirin (ASA) drugs were received from national organization for drug control and research, Giza, Egypt. The phosphate buffer solution (0.1 mol L−1 PBS) used in the present study was composed of a mixture of 1.0 mol L−1 K2HPO4, and 1.0 mol L−1 KH2PO4 and its different pH values (4–9) were adjusted using certain amounts of 0.1 mol L−1 H3PO4, and 0.1 mol L−1 KOH.
For real sample analysis; human urine sample was taken from a healthy volunteer without any pretreatment steps and it was diluted 20 times by 0.1 mol L−1 PBS/ (pH 7.4) to reduce the matrix effect. A stock solution of 1 mmol L−1 OMZ was prepared in 0.1 mol L−1 PBS/ (pH 7.4), and standard additions were performed from OMZ stock solution in 15 mL of diluted urine sample.
Electrochemical cell and apparatus.—All electrochemical studies were performed using a glass cell with three electrodes namely CP, Pt and Ag/AgCl. Electrochemical characterization of the studied surfaces was performed using a BAS-100B electrochemical analyzer. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was carried out using a Volta lab PGZ 301. SEM measurements were achieved using a Quanta 250 FEG instrument. (All the details about the electrodes and the instruments were mentioned elsewhere).37
Construction of working electrode (FeGluCNTCP-SDS).—Bare CP electrode was prepared by the same way as cited elsewhere.38 Modified CP electrode was prepared by mixing 4% of Fe3O4, 15% of CNTs, 20% of Glu, and 61% of graphite powder to obtain 100% total percent of modified paste. To each 1 g of modified graphite, 250 μL of paraffin oil was added, and then mixed in a mortar till a homogenous paste was obtained. This electrode was named as FeGluCNTCP (Scheme 2). Other electrodes were prepared and named as FeCP, CNTCP, GluCP, FeCNTCP, FeGluCP, and GluCNTCP. Further modification was performed by using the electrodes in presence of 10 μL of 0.1 mol L−1 SDS. The resulting electrodes were named as CP-SDS, FeCP-SDS, CNTCP-SDS, GluCP-SDS, FeCNTCP-SDS, FeGluCPSDS, GluCNTCP-SDS,and FeGluCNTCP-SDS.

sections.heading: Results and Discussion
sections.text:
Surface morphology.—The surface morphology of different modified surfaces was investigated using scanning electron microscopy (SEM) to correlate the catalytic activity of the proposed sensor with its morphology. Figs. 1A, 1B, 1C showed the SEM images of FeGluCNTCP, FeGluCNTCP with greater magnification, and FeGluCNTCPSDS, respectively. Fig. 1A showed the SEM of FeGluCNTCP where networking and stem-like structure of CNTs was obtained with assemblies of nano-magnetite with average particles size of about 50 nm31 embedded between the nanotubes, carbon flakes and distributing over their surfaces. Also, glutamine molecules were spread between CNTs and carbon paste flakes. The incorporated modifiers; CNTs, glutamine and Fe3O4 nano-magnetite resulted in a conductive surface with more active sites available for the reaction and higher catalytic performance toward the studied drugs. A greater magnification image of FeGluCNTCP was shown in Fig. 1B. Fig. 1C showed the SEM of FeGluCNTCP-SDS where spongy-like films were observed and attributed to the presence of SDS which enhanced the accumulation of the drug over the electrode surface.
Electro-oxidation behavior of OMZ at different modified surfaces.—Cyclic voltammetry was used to illustrate the electrochemical oxidation of OMZ at different modified surfaces. Fig. 2A showed the electrochemical response of 1 mmol L−1 OMZ/0.1 mol L−1 PBS/pH 7.4 at bare CP and modified CP
Scheme 2. Schematic representation of FeGluCNTCP electrode.
) unless CC License in place (see abstract). ecsdl.org/site/terms_use address. Redistribution subject to ECS terms of use (see 161.116.100.31Downloaded on 2019-02-06 to IP
surfaces (FeCP, CNTCP, GluCP, FeCNTCP, FeGluCP, GluCNTCP, and FeGluCNTCP). Fig. 2B showed the electrochemical response using the same surfaces in presence of SDS. The cyclic voltammetry parameters of OMZ at the as-mentioned surfaces were summarized in Table I. The electro-catalytic oxidation of OMZ at all the studied surfaces depicted an irreversible oxidation process and no reduction peak observed at the backward direction.1,3,4,7 In-situ modifying CP electrode with one modifier as CNT, Glu or Fe3O4 nano-magnetite showed higher current response toward OMZ oxidation compared to CP electrode reflecting the impact of each modifier. Further modification of CP electrode with all the modifiers; CNT, Glu and Fe3O4 in presence of SDS resulted in higher current response compared to all the studied electrodes and depicting the effective synergism between all the modifiers toward the catalytic oxidation of OMZ. The anodic peak current of OMZ at FeGluCNTCP and FeGluCNTCPSDS electrodes was improved by 7.1 folds and 10.5 folds respectively compared to bare CP electrode. CNTs with sp2 carbon units have different nanometers diameter and micrometers length, resulting in high surface/volume ratio, and large surface area with many conductive reactive sites. These active sites can enhance the electrochemical oxidation of OMZ via accelerating the electron transfer rate between the electrode surface, and OMZ molecules.21–23 Fe3O4 magnetic nanoparticles offered good biocompatibility, large surface area/volume ratio, superparamagnetic properties, good conductivity, supporting the cat-
Table I. Summary of CV results at different electrodes for 1 mmol L−1 OMZ/0.1 mol L−1 PBS/pH 7.4.

GluCNTCP 884 290 3.4 FeGluCNTCP 907 610 7.1
CP-SDS 897 300 3.5 FeCP-SDS 906 334 3.9 CNTCP-SDS 941 630 7.3 GluCP-SDS 906 500 5.8 FeCNTCP-SDS 923 750 8.7 FeGluCP-SDS 963 620 7.2

) unless CC License in place (see abstract). ecsdl.org/site/terms_use address. Redistribution subject to ECS terms of use (see 161.116.100.31Downloaded on 2019-02-06 to IP
alytic performance toward OMZ detection.27,29 Modifying CNTs with Fe3O4 added more advantages to their nanocomposite in terms of high sensitivity, facilitated electron transfer kinetics/fast mass transfer, and improved surface area compared to Fe3O4.25–31 Glu offered good catalytic activity and promoted the analytical performance of the nanocomposite.36 The application of limited amounts of SDS helps the accumulation of the OMZ electroactive species at FeGluCNTCP surface that facilitates the electron transfer rate and the current response.37,38 Enhanced electro-catalytic activity was offered by the synergistic combination of CNTs, Fe3O4, Glu, and SDS, which was attributed to the integrated morphology of the resulting surface as discussed in the SEM section.
Influence of operational parameters.—Scan rate.—The influence of scan rate on the oxidation peak current of OMZ at the FeGluCNTCP-SDS electrode was studied using CV mode. (Fig. 3; Inset 1) showed CVs of 0.5 mmol L−1 OMZ/0.1 mol L−1 PBS/pH 7.4 at the modified electrode in the scan rate ranging from 10 to 100 mVs−1. A linear relation was established when ploting the oxidation peak current versus the square root of scan rate as shown in Fig. 3 and was expressed by the following Equation 1:
Ip (μA) = 3244 ν1/2 (V/s)1/2 + 73.6 ( R2 = 0.987) [1]
Only an anodic peak was observed with no cathodic peak in the reverse scan over the studied range of potential which indicated an irreversible electrochemical behavior for OMZ.6,7 Furthermore, the peak potential was shifted to more positive values by increasing the scan rate. Such behavior confirmed that the electrochemical oxidation of OMZ is under irreversible diffusion-control on the surface of the FeGluCNTCP-SDS electrode. Moreover, the relation between log (I) and log (ν) was linear in the studied range (Fig. 3; Inset 2) according to the following equation:
log (I/μA) = 0.462 log (ν/mV. s−1) + 2.12 (R2 = 0.992) [2] A slope of 0.462 (< 0.5) was obtained confirming that the electrochemical oxidation of OMZ at FeGluCNTCP-SDS was conducted under diffusion pathway.10,12
The Randles-Sevcik equation for an irreversible oxidation process was used (Eq. 3);
I irrevp = ±0.496 ( αn′ )1/2 nF AC
( F Dν
RT
)1/2 [3]
Where A is the geometric surface area, α is the transfer coefficient (taken as 0.5, on the basis of assuming that the ratio oxidation peak current for reversible-to-irreversible is 1.27, that is 80% for irreversible processes compared to reversible one), n is the total number of electrons transferred per molecule in the electrochemical process, n′ is the number of electrons transferred per mole before the rate determining step, F is the Faraday’s constant, R is the universal gas constant, T is the absolute temperature (T = 298 k), D is the apparent diffusion coefficient (cm2/s) and ν is the scan rate (V/s).39 The highest diffusion coefficient value 37.3 × 10−4 (cm2 s−1) was obtained using FeGluCNTCP-SDS electrode compared to D value for CPE 0.341 × 10−4 (cm2 s−1) indicating fast charge transfer rate and/or fast mass transfer kinetics.
The electrochemistry of 5 mmol L−1 Fe(CN)62−/Fe(CN)63− in 0.1 mol L−1 KCl was investigated at different surfaces; CP, CNTCP, GluCNTCP, FeGluCNTCP and FeGluCNTCP-SDS. Randles-Sevcik equation for an reversible oxidation process was used to calculate the surface areas of the working electrodes.39
The calculated real surface area in case of FeGluCNTCPSDS (0.508 cm2) was higher than that in case of FeGluCNTCP (0.334 cm2), GluCNTCP (0.302 cm2), CNTCP (0.236 cm2) and bare CP (0.163 cm2). The results indicated the enhancement in the real surface area of the FeGluCNTCP-SDS sensor upon the inclusion of CNTs, Glu, and Fe3O4 nano-oxides inside the CP and further in presence of SDS.
Supporting electrolyte pH.—In this part we assessed the effect of pH for the supporting electrolyte used as it affects the response of FeGluCNTCP-SDS electrode toward OMZ electro-oxidation. (Fig. 4; Inset 1) showed the CV study for 1 mmol L−1 OMZ/0.1 mmol L−1 of PBS in the pH range 4 → 9. The peak potential shifted toward the negative direction by increasing the pH value of the buffer solution which indicated that the electrocatalytic oxidation of OMZ at the FeGluCNTCP-SDS electrode was a pH-dependent reaction and that protons were involved in the electrochemical process. Fig. 4 showed a linear relationship between the peak potential (Ep) and the pH (4.0 → 9 .0) with a slope of –60.5 mV/pH ∼ Nernstian slope, which was expressed by the following Equation 4:
Epa (mV) = 1393 − 60.5 pH ( R2 = 0.987) [4]
The mechanism of electro-oxidation of OMZ was shown in Scheme 3 involving 1H+/1e−.2,4,7,10 The oxidation process involved one electron removal followed by deprotonation producing a cation radical which then reacted with water producing a hydroxylated product.2,4,7,10 The effect of the pH on the anodic peak current of OMZ was shown in
) unless CC License in place (see abstract). ecsdl.org/site/terms_use address. Redistribution subject to ECS terms of use (see 161.116.100.31Downloaded on 2019-02-06 to IP
Scheme 3. Oxidation mechanism of OMZ.
(Fig. 4; Inset 2) indicating a maximum value of peak current obtained at pH 7.4. Thus, pH 7.4 was chosen for this study.
Stability, precision, robustness, and ruggedness.—Figure 5 showed the repeated cycles stability of 1 mmol L−1 OMZ/0.1 mol L−1 PBS/pH 7.4 at FeGluCNTCP-SDS up to 30 cycles. A good stable electrochemical response in terms of anodic peak current and potential values was observed confirming the antifouling feature of this surface. It is crucial to test the stability and precision of the response of the sensor to realize its applicability for OMZ determination. We examined the intra-day and inter-day precision toward OMZ determination. The intra-day and inter-day precision were tested using the following procedure: a given concentration of OMZ was tested in a single measurement with the same sensor for four times; or in four separate measurements for four times using four sensors made independently, respectively. The calculated relative standard deviation values (RSD) were 1.39%, and 0.8% for intra-day and inter-day precision, respectively. These low values reflected the applicability of the proposed sensor toward OMZ determination with response stability and good precision.
The robustness of the proposed method was also examined by checking the stability of the current response of the proposed sensor toward OMZ upon the influence of slight variation in the experimental conditions. The studied parameters were pH (7.4 ± 0.2), volume of SDS (10 μL ± 0.01), and time before measurement (2 minutes ± 20 s). The RSD values were 0.69%, 0.71% and 2.08% respectively manifesting the robustness and credibility of the suggested method in real analysis of OMZ. In addition, the ruggedness of the proposed method was evaluated by the analytical testing of the same concentration of OMZ by different analysts under the same optimized experimental conditions using the same instrument on two different days. RSD values of 0.21%, and 0.7% were obtained for the first and second analyst, respectively showing the ruggedness of the proposed method toward OMZ determination.
Analytical performance of the FeGluCNTCP-SDS sensor.—In this part of the work, we used differential pulse voltammetry (DPV) for the quantitative assay of OMZ in human urine, as a real sample, using the FeGluCNTCP-SDS sensor in buffer (pH = 7.4). For real
sample analysis; human urine sample was diluted 20 times by 0.1 mol L−1 PBS/ (pH 7.4) to reduce the matrix effect. A stock solution of 1 mmol L−1 OMZ/0.1 mol L−1 PBS/(pH 7.4) was prepared, and standard additions were performed from OMZ stock solution in 15 mL of diluted urine sample. DPVs were recorded for a series of OMZ concentrations (0.01–100 μmol L−1) in diluted urine/PBS (pH 7.4); we observed that the oxidation peak current increases with increasing in the concentration of OMZ (Figure 6; Inset). The peak current (Ipa) was found to be linearly dependent on the concentration in range of 0.01–100 μmol L−1 as illustrated in Fig. 6 according to the following Equation 5:
Ip (μA) = 0.536 C (μmol L−1) + 24.4 ( R2 = 0.992) [5]
In the calibration curve, and for each of the concentration of OMZ, three measurements were carried out to obtain the average oxidation current value. We also determined the sensitivity (0.536 μA/μmol L−1), the detection limit (DL; 3.3 nmol L−1) and the quantification limit (QL; 11.05 nmol L−1) for the sensor under investigation. The following equations (Eqs. 6 and 7) were used to calculate the detection limit (DL) and quantification limit (QL);
DL = 3 s/b [6]
QL = 10 s/b [7] Where s is the standard deviation and b is the calibration curve slope.
FeGluCNTCP-SDS showed good sensitivity and low DL toward OMZ as indicated in Table II.
Accuracy of the proposed method was assessed from recovery percentage after adding known amounts of OMZ with different concentrations in diluted human urine sample (in this step, it was necessary to dilute the sample as previously mentioned with the PBS buffer). The relevant concentrations were estimated from the linear calibration relations using FeGluCNTCP-SDS electrode. The experiments were repeated five times for each of the studied concentrations. The corresponding recovery values for the performed assay were in the range of 99% to 102.4% for OMZ. The summary of recoveries and RSD values
) unless CC License in place (see abstract). ecsdl.org/site/terms_use address. Redistribution subject to ECS terms of use (see 161.116.100.31Downloaded on 2019-02-06 to IP
were displayed in Table III. The above results confirmed the practicality of using the FeGluCNTCP-SDS electrode for the determination of OMZ in human urine.
Analysis of OMZ and aspirin in their pharmaceutical tablets.— The specificity of the proposed method was demonstrated by examining the possible interference from common compounds that could be encountered from tablet excipients. In order to study the applica-
bility of the FeGluCNTCP-SDS electrode in the pharmaceutical sample analysis, two commercial medicinal samples namely Gastrazole (20 mg OMZ/tablet) and Rivo (320 mg ASA/tablet) were investigated. The tablets were prepared for test using the following procedure: (i) the tablet was carefully ground and stoichiometrically dissolved in the PBS buffer (pH = 7.4); (ii) the sample was sonicated for 10 minutes and (iii) the solution was then filtered off to remove the non-dissolved residue. Measured volumes from the stock solution of each tablet solution were transferred to the electrochemical cell. The recovery test of OMZ and ASA was performed over their concentration ranges 0.2 → 60 μM, and 50 →120 μM respectively using DPV mode. Recovery studies were carried out after the addition of known standard amount of each drug (2 μM) to the pre-analyzed formulations of OMZ and ASA separately. The tests were repeated five times for each of the studied concentrations. The recovery and relative standard deviations were shown in Table (IVA and IVB). The results showed good precision and accuracy of the proposed method.
Interferences study in phosphate buffer solution.—Simultaneous detection of OMZ with interfering compounds.— The capability of FeGluCNTCP-SDS electrode to discriminate between OMZ and other interfering compounds present in biological fluids like epinephrine (EP), paracetamol (APAP), ascorbic acid (AA), and uric acid (UA) is

) unless CC License in place (see abstract). ecsdl.org/site/terms_use address. Redistribution subject to ECS terms of use (see 161.116.100.31Downloaded on 2019-02-06 to IP
necessary from the application point of view. Figs. 7A, 7B, and 7C showed the DPVs of 1 mmol L−1 OMZ /1 mmol L−1 EP, 1 mmol L−1 OMZ/1 mmol L−1 APAP, and 0.5 mmol L−1 OMZ/10 mmol L−1 AA /1 mmol L−1 UA, each mixture prepared in 0.1 mol L−1 PBS/pH 7.40 using CP, and FeGluCNTCP-SDS electrodes, respectively. Two well separated peaks were obtained with higher current responses using FeGluCNTCP-SDS electrode at +153 mV, +844 mV for EP
and OMZ and at +452 and +848 for APAP, and OMZ, respectively compared to bare CP electrode. Also, three defined separated peaks were observed in case of AA, UA, and OMZ with higher current responses using FeGluCNTCP-SDS electrode at +60 mV, +383 mV and +942 mV, respectively compared to undefined overlapped peaks obtained at CP electrode.
Determination of OMZ in the presence of ascorbic acid (AA) and uric acid (UA).—The electrochemical assays of diverse drugs in biological fluids suffer from some interfering compounds such as AA or UA present within the assay mixture. Fig. 8A showed the DPVs of OMZ in the concentration range (1 → 50 μmol L−1) in presence of 3 mmol L−1 of AA and 0.3 mmol L−1 of UA at FeGluCNTCP-SDS electrode. (Fig. 8A; Inset) showed the calibration curve of OMZ in the concertation range (1 → 50 μmol L−1) with the linear regression Equation 8:
Ip (μA) = 0.46 C ( μmol L−1 ) + 8.1 (R2 = 0.988) [8] The sensitivity and the DL were 0.46 μA/μmol L−1 and 3.9 nmol L−1 respectively.
Simultaneous determination of OMZ and APAP.—Acetaminophen (APAP) is customary applied as a pain killer and for fever relief. Therefore, determination of OMZ in presence of APAP is essential for patients taking these medication and to examine the antiinterference ability of the sensor.38 Fig. 8B depicted the DPVs of OMZ and APAP using FeGluCNTCP-SDS electrode. The insets of Figure 8B depicted the linear relations between the oxidation peak currents and the variation in concentrations of OMZ and APAP in the range (1→80 μmol L−1). The following Equations 9, 10 represented these relations.
Ip (μA) = 0.30 C ( μmol L−1 ) + 10.1 (R2 = 0.990) [9] The sensitivity and DL for OMZ were 0.30 μA/μmol L−1 and 5.9 nmol L−1 respectively.
Ip (μA) = 0.21 C ( μmol L−1 ) + 7.9 (R2 = 0.998) [10] The sensitivity and DL for APAP were 0.21 μA/μmol L−1 and 8.5 nmol L−1 respectively.
Simultaneous determination of OMZ and DA.—Alteration in dopamine (DA) level is very important to be considered for patients under ongoing treatment for heart problems and its determination is essential in presence of OMZ. Two sharp oxidation peaks were observed for a binary mixture of OMZ and DA. The concentration of DA was kept constant at (10 μmol L−1) while varying the concentration of OMZ (0.8 → 40 μmol L−1), using FeGluCNTCP-SDS (Fig. 8C). The inset of Figure 8C depicted the relation between the oxidation peak current and the variation in concentration of OMZ. The data showed linear relation and was represented by the following Equation 11:
Ip (μA) = 0.56 C ( μmol L−1 ) + 9.4 (R2 = 0.993) [11] The sensitivity and DL for OMZ were 0.56 μA/μmol L−1 and 3.2 nmol L−1 respectively.
Two oxidation peaks were observed for the determination of a binary mixture of OMZ and DA. The concentration of OMZ was kept constant at (10 μmol L−1) while varying the concentration of OMZ (0.8 → 40 μmol L−1) using FeGluCNTCP-SDS (Fig. 8D). The inset of Figure 8D depicted the relation between the oxidation peak current and the variation in concentration of DA. The data showed linear relation and was represented by the following Equation 12:
Ip (μA) = 0.70 C ( μmol L−1 ) + 9.4 (R2 = 0.971) [12] The sensitivity and DL for DA were 0.70 μA/μmol L−1 and 2.5
nmol L−1 respectively.
) unless CC License in place (see abstract). ecsdl.org/site/terms_use address. Redistribution subject to ECS terms of use (see 161.116.100.31Downloaded on 2019-02-06 to IP
) unless CC License in place (see abstract). ecsdl.org/site/terms_use address. Redistribution subject to ECS terms of use (see 161.116.100.31Downloaded on 2019-02-06 to IP
Figure 8E showed the DPVs for simultaneous determination of OMZ and DA in the concentration range from (0.8 → 40 μmol L−1) using FeGluCNTCP-SDS electrode (Fig. 8E). The insets of Figure 8E depicted the relation between the oxidation peak currents and the variation in concentrations of OMZ and DA. The data showed linear relations and were represented by the following Equations 13,14:
Ip (μA) = 0.40 C ( μmol L−1 ) + 11.1 (R2 = 0.974) [13] The sensitivity and DL for OMZ were 0.40 μA/μmol L−1 and 3.9 nmol L−1 respectively.
Ip (μA) = 0.46 C ( μmol L−1 ) + 9.8 (R2 = 0.992) [14] The sensitivity and DL for DA were 0.46 μA/μmol L−1 and 4.4 nmol L−1 respectively.
Simultaneous determination of a combination medicine of ASA and OMZ.—An effective medication for cardiovascular diseases and gastrointestinal disorders patients is the binary therapy of ASA and OMZ.20 Therefore, their simultaneous determination is very crucial for patients under treatment. Two well-separated oxidation peaks were observed for a binary mixture of OMZ and ASA in phosphate buffer solution (PBS) as the concentration of OMZ changed from (0.8 →50 μmol L−1) while the concentration of ASA was kept constant at 150 μmol L−1 using FeGluCNTCP-SDS (Fig. 9A). The inset of Figure 9A depicted the relation between the oxidation peak current and the variation in concentration of OMZ. The data showed linear relation and was represented by the following Equation 15:
Ip (μA) = 0.51 C ( μmol L−1 ) + 7.53 (R2 = 0.977) [15] The sensitivity and DL values for OMZ were 0.51 μA/μmol L−1 and 3.5 nmol L−1 respectively.
Two distinct oxidation peaks were observed for a binary mixture of OMZ and ASA as the concentration of ASA changed from (20 →150 μmol L−1) while the concentration of OMZ was kept constant at 20 μmol L−1 using FeGluCNTCP-SDS (Fig. 9B). The inset of Figure 9B depicted the relation between the oxidation peak current and the variation in concentration of ASA. The data showed linear relation and was represented by the following Equation 16:
Ip (μA) = 0.20 C ( μmol L−1 ) + 1.61 (R2 = 0.977) [16] The sensitivity and DL values for ASA were 0.20 μA/μmol L−1 and 8.9 nmol L−1 respectively.
No previous work cited the application of FeGluCNTCP-SDS electrode for simultaneous determination of OMZ and ASA in their mixture. The results showed excellent peak potentials separation for the oxidation of OMZ and ASA. This was performed by simultaneously changing the concentrations of OMZ and ASA and recording the DPVs using FeGluCNTCP-SDS electrode (Fig. 9C). (Figure 9C; Insets) depicted the relation between the oxidation peak currents and the variation in concentrations of OMZ and ASA in the following ranges (0.6 to 60 μmol L−1) and (20 to 170 μmol L−1) respectively. The data showed linear relations and were represented by the following Equations 17,18:
Ip (μA) = 0.54 C ( μmol L−1 ) + 8.65 (R2 = 0.964) [17] The sensitivity and DL for OMZ were 0.54 μA/μmol L−1 and 3.3 nmol L−1 respectively.
Ip (μA) = 0.15 C ( μmol L−1 ) + 13.65 (R2 = 0.973) [18] The sensitivity and DL for ASA were 0.15 μA/μmol L−1 and 11.8 nmol L−1 respectively.
According to the above results, it was observed that the sensitivity of the FeGluCNTCP-SDS electrode toward OMZ in presence of ASA (0.51 -0.54 μmol L−1) is very close to the sensitivity of the sensor in OMZ only (0.536 μA/μmol L−1) demonstrating the independent oxidation processes of these compounds at FeGluCNTCP-SDS elec-
) unless CC License in place (see abstract). ecsdl.org/site/terms_use address. Redistribution subject to ECS terms of use (see 161.116.100.31Downloaded on 2019-02-06 to IP
trode and that the simultaneous determination of OMZ and ASA was achieved without any interference.
Electrochemical characterization of different surfaces using EIS.—Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy was used as a reliable technique to give information on oxide characteristics, reaction parameters, surface integrity and porosity, electron/mass transport, electrode/electrolyte interface characteristics, etc. EIS experiments were performed in a solution containing 1 mmol L−1 OMZ/0.1 mol L−1 PBS/pH 7.4 at the corresponding oxidation potential of OMZ at CP-SDS, and FeGluCNTCP-SDS surfaces at an AC frequency in the range of 0.1 Hz to 100 kHz. The electrochemical impedance spectra (Nyquist and Bode plots) were shown in Figs. 10A,10B, respectively. The equivalent circuit used for fitting the EIS experimental data for the FeGluCNTCP-SDS was shown in the inset of Fig. 10A. The elements of this circuit are solution resistance (Rs), charge transfer resistance (Rct), film resistance (Rf), constant phase elements instead of capacitors representing inhomogeneity of reaction rates and surface roughness (Yo1 and Yo2) with their corresponding exponents (n, m; with values < one), and Warburg impedance Ws1 due to the diffusion of ions of analyte from solution bulk to the surface of electrode. The parameters used for fitting the data for the CP-SDS electrode are Rs, Rct, Ws1 and Yo1. The uncompensated resistance of the solution, Rs, showed a relatively high value in case of CP-SDS electrode compared to FeGluCNTCP-SDS electrode. The presence of SDS at the electrode helped the “pre-concentration” of the electroactive species to the vicinity of the electrode/electrolyte region. The resistance element represented by Rct was related to the kinetics of the charge transfer reaction at the interface. The Rct value for the proposed sensor had a noticeable lower value compared to the CP-SDS electrode as represented by the data of Table V. In the Bode plot (Figure 10B), the relation between the absolute value of the impedance (Z) and frequency was characterized by a “flat” component that spaned the high frequency region (in case of CP-SDS electrode), and the high and midfrequecy regions (in case of the sensor). At high frequency region, the total resistance is the sum of all types of resistances connected in series; this includes the ionic, charge transfer and film resistances. The constant phase element, Yo1, represented the roughness of the surface and the data revealed a capacitive behavior that combined the double layer capacitance (n > 0.5). For the CP-SDS electrode the capacitive behavior showed a steady behavior up to a frequency of 103 Hz, however an inflection is observed below this value. Similar behavior was observed for the sensor up to a frequency of 103 Hz revealing relatively lower impedance values. The lowest phase angle shift was observed at 10 Hz and 0.5 Hz for CP-SDS and sensor electrodes, respectively.
The increase in the resistive value for CP-SDS compared to the sensor electrode was manifested in the observed relatively higher values for the current obtained for the oxidation of electroactive species at the sensor electrode. The Warburg component (Ws1) showed higher value at CP-SDS revealing the constraint faced at the interface of the electrode. The fitting data were represented by solid lines and a good matching was achieved between the fitting and experimental data as shown in Fig. 10. A semicircle with large diameter corresponded to high electron transfer resistance at CP-SDS electrode as depicted from Fig. 10A. But only semi-linear part was depicted at FeGluCNTCP-SDS electrode reflecting a lower charge transfer resistance and faster charge transfer kinetics. Besides, a significant decrease in the total impedance in the (Nyquist and Bode plots) using FeGluCNTCP-SDS electrode compared to CP-SDS electrode confirming the electro-catalytic performance of the proposed surface. A summary of the EIS fitting data at CP-SDS and FeGluCNTCP-SDS electrodes was shown in Table V. An observable decrease in the values of Rs, and Rct was depicted upon the modification of CP with nano-magnetite, glutamine, CNTs and SDS confirming the enhanced performance of the nanocomposite. A decrease in the value of Ws1 was obtained upon modification confirming faster diffusion kinetics. Also, there was an obvious increase in the value of constant phase element (Yo1) for FeGluCNTCP-SDS electrode compared to CP-SDS
electrode confirming higher ionic accumulation at the proposed surface. In conclusion, the nanocomposite components offered enhanced surface area, improved conductivity, and increased catalytic activity of the proposed film.
) unless CC License in place (see abstract). ecsdl.org/site/terms_use address. Redistribution subject to ECS terms of use (see 161.116.100.31Downloaded on 2019-02-06 to IP

sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text: The present study introduced an electrochemical approach for the simultaneous determination of aspirin and omeprazole for patients suffered from cardiovascular diseases and under the risk of gastric ulcers. This approach was based on the modification of CP with CNTs, glutamine, and nano-magnetite in the presence of SDS. Modification of CNTs with glutamine resulted in more conductive surface and higher analytical performance toward OMZ sensing compared to CNTs. Further modification of CNTs/Glu with iron nano-magnetite resulted in higher current response and better electro-catalytic activity toward OMZ in presence of SDS. FeGluCNTCP-SDS offered good sensitivity, lower detection limit besides better accuracy and precision compared to other surfaces cited in literature. The proposed surface was utilized for the determination of OMZ and aspirin in Gastrazole and Rivo pharmaceutical tablets, respectively. The proposed surface can discriminate OMZ in the presence of other interfering compounds like APAP, DA, AA and UA. Also, it can simultaneously and sensitively detect OMZ and ASA with nano-molar detection limits for both. So, the application in the electrochemical sensing of a combination of OMZ and other drugs was enhanced by using a modified FeGluCNTCP-SDS electrode.

metadata.abstractText: In the present study, we introduce a direct and sensitive voltammetry approach for the simultaneous determination of aspirin (ASA) and omeprazole (OMZ) for patients suffering from cardiovascular diseases and gastrointestinal disorders. Low dose of ASA can be used for the prevention of cardiovascular diseases which is considered the most severe cause of mortality worldwide. On the other hand, OMZ can reduce the risk of gastric ulcers and gastrointestinal damage associated with ASA. The used electrode was constructed by in situ-modification with multi-walled carbon nanotubes, glutamine, and nano-magnetite in presence of sodium dodecyl sulfate (FeGluCNTCP-SDS). Using this sensor, the limits of detection were 11.9 nmol·L−1 and 3.3 nmol·L−1 for ASA and OMZ, respectively. The proposed sensor was used for the determination of OMZ in presence of dopamine, paracetamol, ascorbic acid, and uric acid without noticeable interference in their binary or ternary mixtures. The proposed surface showed good analytical performance toward OMZ determination and has a promising application for the electrochemical sensing of other drugs of pharmaceutical importance. © 2019 The Electrochemical Society. [DOI: 10.1149/2.1241902jes]
